DialogueOption.Text: I heard you delayed your launch date several times! Why’s that?

Dialogue.Page: Ah, I’m guessing you heard about this from Mica?
I hope you didn’t take too long to take off - or they’ll be telling future space cadets about how you delayed your launch for generations to come, too!
As I've told them many times.. The reason I delayed my launch date was because sand on Ember Twin was flowing to Ash Twin on my launch date.
Since I was planning to explore Ash Twin on my first trip, the sand burying it would’ve made exploring anything rather hard.
That’s why I opted to delay my launch - though more times than I'd have liked - until the sand began to flow back to Ember Twin!

DialogueOption.Text: The sand flows back to Ash Twin?

Dialogue.Page: Indeed! Have you seen the colossal towers of solar panels on each of the Ash Twin's poles? They are truly a magnificent sight to behold.
I wished to visit Ash Twin to get a closer look at these wondrous structures. The Nomai must have been able to harness an incredible amount of energy with them!
They look truly striking, set on each of the planet's poles.. Though it makes me wonder why they didn't build Ember Twin's solar panels on the poles as well.
Fantastic view aside: you might be able to glean more about them with that new translator tool of yours! I highly recommend visiting them when you get the chance

DialogueOption.Text: I will, but tell me more about the Twins' shifting sands!

Dialogue.Page: Why, yes! Haven’t you noticed before?
Right now, sand is flowing from Ash Twin to Ember Twin - but the process eventually reverses. In fact, if you wait, you should be able to see it beginning to flow back to Ash Twin!
We're not completely sure why the sand flows back and forth between the Twins, but it seems to be a natural phenomena.
Even stranger, the process seems to happen in very precise intervals.. It's been consistent every time we've measured it. It's terribly fascinating!

DialogueOption.Text: How long do you think it'd take for sand to start flowing back to Ash Twin again?

Dialogue.Page: Gladly!

DialogueOption.Text: How long do you think it'd take for sand to start flowing back to Ash Twin again?

Dialogue.Page: Hm... It will take a while longer, I believe.
Come back once more of the sand has drained off from Ash Twin, and I might be able to give you a more precise answer then!
If you’re feeling impatient, feel free to take a nap by the campfire to pass the time.
I have set up this camp here to avoid the sand column's path - so you need not worry about the sand column wandering this way while you rest.

DialogueOption.Text: Cool, cool. Tell me about what you found on Ash Twin, though!

Dialogue.Page: Goodness! That's right, that's what we were discussing at first, wasn't it? My apologies for rambling!

DialogueOption.Text: I will, but tell me more about the Twins' shifting sands!
I found out what causes the sand to flow between the twins.

Dialogue.Page: How fascinating..
So if I understand correctly.. Gravity from the sun and the twin closer to the sun cause a combined force that pulls sand to the other twin when the twins orbit into alignment?
It sounds peculiar.. but it makes complete sense now that you've spelled it out!

Surely, the gravitational centre of the solar system combining its pull with another planet would cause some interesting tidal effects. And you said the Nomai called this phenomenon the "sunless day"?
Incredible work, hatchling! Solving a mystery that has puzzled me for ages on your first expedition is truly something else.
After we gather more conclusive data on this phenomenon, let us mark your findings with a new exhibit in the village museum, and celebrate with some sap wine!
